The company employs approximately 640 people,{{cite web|last=Coleman|first=Kyle|title=Green Energy Pioneer Barry Ellsworth Announces Nevada US Senate Run Against Corrupt Career Politician Shelley Berkley|url=https://news.yahoo.com/green-energy-pioneer-barry-ellsworth-announces-nevada-us-181635650.html|work=yahoo.news|accessdate=31 January 2012}} and was founded by Barry Ellsworth. Green Plains Inc. is listed on the [[NASDAQ]] Stock Exchange as GPRE. ==Corporate events== * '''2014''' - Green Plains changed their name from Green Plains Renewable Energy, Inc. to Green Plains Inc. in May 2014.{{Cite web|url=http://files.shareholder.com/downloads/GPRE/3863986455x0x755656/0CD08A63-422F-4070-B889-75B56F44FF87/GPRE_News_2014_5_16_General_Releases.pdf|title=Green Plains Renewable Energy, Inc. Changes Name to Green Plains Inc.|last=|first=|date=May 26, 2014|website=Globe Newswire|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}} * '''2012''' - Green Plains completed sale of agribusiness assets including 12 grain elevators in northwestern Iowa and western Tennessee to [[The Andersons]] in December 2012.{{cite web|url=http://investor.gpreinc.com/releasedetail.cfm?releaseid=724597|title=Green Plains Completes Sale of Agribusiness Assets - Green Plains Inc.|last=|first=|date=December 3, 2012|website=Green Plains Inc.|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}} ** [[XMS Capital Partners]] served as financial advisor to Green Plains in the transaction. ==See also== {{portal|Companies|Renewable energy}} * [[Biofuel in the United States]] * [[Ethanol fuel in the United States]] * [[List of renewable energy companies by stock exchange]] * [[Renewable Fuels Association]] ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== * [http://www.ethanolproducer.com/articles/8539/construction-of-five-acre-algae-farm-begins-at-ethanol-plant "Construction of five-acre algae farm begins at ethanol plant"]{{spaced ndash}}from [http://www.ethanolproducer.com Ethanol Producer Magazine] [[Category:Companies based in Omaha, Nebraska]] [[Category:Grain companies of the United States]] [[Category:Alcohol fuel producers]] {{US-energy-company-stub}} {{Renewable-energy-stub}}

{{multiple issues| {{sections|date=July 2018}} {{more citations needed|date=July 2018}} {{prose|date=July 2018}} {{lead too short|date=July 2018}} {{context|date=July 2018}} }} '''Hydrogen leak testing''' is the normal way in which a [[hydrogen]] [[pressure vessel]] or installation is checked for [[leak]]s or [[flaw (defect)|flaw]]s. This usually involves charging hydrogen as a tracer gas into the device undergoing testing, with any leaking gas detected by hydrogen sensors.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.fukuda-jp.com/en/leak/f03/|title=Mechanisms of the Hydrogen Leak Test|last=|first=|date=|website=www.fukuda-jp.com|language=en|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2018-10-18}}</ref> Various test mechanisms have been devised.
==Test mechanisms==
=== Hydrostatic test === In the [[hydrostatic test]], a vessel is filled with a nearly incompressible liquid – usually [[water]] or [[oil]] – and examined for leaks or permanent changes in shape. The test pressure is always considerably higher than the operating pressure to give a margin for safety, typically 150% of the operating pressure.
=== Burst test === In the [[burst test]], a vessel is filled with a gas and tested for leaks. The test pressure is always considerably more than the operating pressure to give a margin for safety, typically 200% or more of the operating pressure.
=== Helium leak test === The [[Helium mass spectrometer|helium leak test]] uses [[helium]] (the lightest inert gas) as a tracer gas and detects it in concentrations as small as one part in 10 million. The helium is selected primarily because it penetrates small leaks readily, is inert and will not react with the test piece while having a naturally low quantity in air making detection less complicated. It is possible to detect leaks as small as 5.10<sup>−10</sup> Pa·m<sup>3</sup>/s in vacuum mode and modern digital machines can detect 5.10<sup>−10</sup> Pa·m<sup>3</sup>/s in sniffing mode.
=== Vacuum test === Usually a vacuum inside the object is created with an external pump connected to the instrument. Alternatively helium can be injected inside the product while the product itself is enclosed in a vacuum chamber connected to the instrument. In this case, burst and leakage tests can be combined in one operation.
=== Hydrogen sensor test === During the [[hydrogen sensor]] test, the object is filled with a mixture of 5% [[hydrogen]]/ 95% [[nitrogen]], (below 5.7% hydrogen) is non-flammable (ISO-10156). This is called typically a sniffing test. The handprobe connected to the microelectronic hydrogen sensors is used to check the object. An audiosignal increases in proximity of a leak. Detection of leaks go down to 5x10<sup>−7</sup> cubic centimeters per second.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.reedlink.com/SingleArticle~ContentId~11957~pub~IA.html |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2006-08-06 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20060111211007/http://www.reedlink.com/SingleArticle~ContentId~11957~pub~IA.html |archivedate=2006-01-11 |df= }}</ref> Compared to the helium test, hydrogen is cheaper than helium, no need for a vacuum, the instrument could be cheaper but is not as sensitive as a helium leak detector so will not find smaller leaks.
Chemo-chromic hydrogen leak detectors are materials that can be proactively applied to a connection or fitting. In the event of a hydrogen leak, the chemo-chromic material changes color to alert an inspector that a leak is present. Chemo-chromic indicators can also be added to silicone tapes for hydrogen detection purposes.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.detectape.com/ |title=DetecTape H2 - Low Cost Visual Hydrogen Leak Detector |publisher=Detectape.com |date= |accessdate=2018-07-10}}</ref>
==See also== * [[Hydrogen analyzer]] * [[Hydrogen piping]] * [[Hydrogen safety]] * [[Hydrogen station]] * [[Tracer-gas leak testing]] method * [[Tubing (material)]]
==References== {{reflist}}
== External links == * [http://www.leakpedia.com Leakpedia – The free wiki encyclopedia about the industrial leak testing] * [http://www.detectape.com Detectape – Hydrogen detection silicone tape]

[[International standard]] '''[[International Electrotechnical Commission|IEC]] 61400-25''' (Communications for monitoring and control of wind power plants, TC 88) provides uniform information exchange for monitoring and control of wind power plants. This addresses the issue of proprietary communication systems utilizing a wide variety of protocols, labels, semantics, etc., thus enabling one to exchange information with different wind power plants independently of a vendor. It is a subset of [[IEC 61400]]; a set of standards for designing wind turbines.<ref>[http://webstore.iec.ch/preview/info_iec61400-1%7Bed3.0%7Den.pdf International Standard IEC 61400-1, Third Edition] ''[[International Electrotechnical Commission]]'', August 2005. Accessed: 12 March 2011.</ref>
The IEC 61400-25 standard is a basis for simplifying the roles that the [[wind turbine]] and [[SCADA]] systems have to play. The crucial part of the [[wind power plant]] information, information exchange methods, and communication stacks are standardized. They build a basis to which procurement specifications and contracts could easily refer.
The standard has specified five mapping (IEC 61400-25-4) to communication protocol stacks in order to address the real wind power business needs for communication. The mappings specified in the part of IEC 61400-25 comprises a mapping to [[SOAP]]-based [[web service]]s, [[OLE for process control|OPC]]/[[XML]]-[[OPC Data Access|DA]], [[IEC 61850]]-8-1 [[Manufacturing Message Specification|MMS]], [[IEC 60870-5]]-104 and a mapping to [[DNP3]].
== Interoperability == For supporting the interoperability of the IEC 61400-25 standard, a user group was formed with a high degree of cooperation with user groups on [[IEC 61850]] and [[DNP3]]. Users, manufacturers, service providers, and system integrators with interest in the specific issues on interoperatibility are recommend to address the IEC 61400-25 user group on http://www.USE61400-25.com/.
== See also == * [[IEC 61850]]
== External links == * [http://www.iec.ch IEC Standards Website] * [http://www.USE61400-25.com IEC 61400-25 User Group web site]

[[File:Land Trust Alliance.png|thumb|Land Trust Alliance logo]]
The '''Land Trust Alliance''', originally formed in 1982 as the Land Trust Exchange, is a national conservation organization representing more than 1,700 [[land trust]]s across the [[United States]]. The organization describes its objectives as working to increase the pace and quality of conservation by advocating favorable tax policies, training land trusts in best practices, and working to ensure the permanence of conservation in the face of continuing threats. The Land Trust Alliance is based in Washington, DC. As of December 2010, national, regional and local land trusts have conserved a total of 47 million acres (190,000 km<sup>²</sup>) of land in America.<ref>[http://www.landtrustalliance.org/land-trusts/land-trust-census/census The Land Trust Alliance] - Official website, October 2011.</ref>

[[Image:BioethanolsCountryOfOrigin.jpg|right|250px|thumb|UK figures for the [[carbon intensity]] of bioethanol and [[fossil fuels]]. This graph assumes that all bioethanols are burnt in their country of origin and that previously existing cropland is used to grow the feedstock. No [[ILUC|indirect land-use changes]] are included.<ref name=UKRTFO>{{cite web| url=http://www.dft.gov.uk/pgr/roads/environment/rtfo/govrecrfa.pdf| archive-url=http://webarchive.nationalarchives.gov.uk/20161124161624/http://www.dft.gov.uk/pgr/roads/environment/rtfo/govrecrfa.pdf| dead-url=yes| archive-date=2016-11-24|format=PDF|title= Carbon and Sustainability Reporting Within the Renewable Transport Fuel Obligation|publisher=Department of Transport, United Kingdom |date=January 2008 |accessdate=2011-10-12}}</ref>]] A '''low-carbon fuel standard''' (LCFS) is a rule enacted to reduce [[carbon intensity]] in transportation fuels as compared to conventional [[petroleum fuel]]s, such as [[gasoline]] and [[Diesel fuel|diesel]]. The most common low-carbon fuels are [[alternative fuel]]s and cleaner [[fossil fuel]]s, such as [[natural gas]] ([[Compressed Natural Gas|CNG]] and [[Liquefied petroleum gas|LPG]]). The main purpose of a low-carbon fuel standard is to decrease [[carbon dioxide]] emissions associated with vehicles powered by various types of internal combustion engines while also considering the entire [[Life cycle assessment|life cycle]] ("well to wheels"), in order to reduce the [[carbon footprint]] of transportation.
The first low-carbon fuel standard mandate in the world was enacted by [[California]] in 2007, with specific eligibility criteria defined by the [[California Air Resources Board]] (CARB) in April 2009 but taking effect in January 2011.<ref name="SciAm">{{cite web| url=http://www.scientificamerican.com/article.cfm?id=california-adopts-low-carF|title= California Adopts Low-Carbon Fuel Standard|author=Debra Kahn |publisher=[[Scientific American]] |date=2009-04-24|accessdate=2009-05-04}} {{Dead link|date=October 2010|bot=H3llBot}}</ref><ref name="SFG042409"/><ref name="NYT042409"/><ref name="CNN0409"/> Similar legislation was approved in [[British Columbia]] in April 2008,<ref name="Vancouver08"/> and by [[European Union]] which proposed its legislation in January 2007 and which was adopted in December 2008.<ref name="EU08"/> The [[United Kingdom]] is implementing its [[Renewable Transport Fuel Obligation]] Program, which also applies the concept of low-carbon fuels.<ref name="UKRTFO"/>
Several bills have been proposed in the [[United States]] for similar low-carbon fuel regulation at a national level but with less stringent standards than California.<ref name="TwoBillion">{{Cite book | last = Sperling, Daniel and Deborah Gordon | title = Two billion cars: driving toward sustainability | year = 2009 | pages= 194–196 | publisher = [[Oxford University Press]], New York| isbn = 978-0-19-537664-7}}</ref> As of early 2010 none have been approved. The [[U.S. Environmental Protection Agency]] (EPA) issued its final rule regarding the expanded [[Renewable Fuel Standard]] (RFS2) for 2010 and beyond on February 3, 2010.<ref name=EPArule2010/> This ruling, as mandated by the [[Energy Independence and Security Act of 2007]] (EISA), included [[ILUC|direct emissions and significant indirect emissions from land use changes]].<ref name=EPAdraft/><ref name=EPA0509/><ref name=EPA2010/>
==California Low-Carbon Fuel Standard==
[[Californian Governor]] [[Arnold Schwarzenegger]] issued [[Executive order (United States)|Executive Order]] S-1-07 on January 19, 2007 to enact a low-carbon fuel standard (LCFS).<ref name="GovernorPR">{{cite web|url=http://gov.ca.gov/index.php?/press-release/5074|title= Gov. Schwarzenegger Issues Directive to Establish World's First Low Carbon Standard for Transportation Fuels|publisher=Office of the Governor (Press Release)|date=2007-01-07 |accessdate=2009-04-23}}</ref><ref name="CARB01"/> The LCFS requires [[oil refinery|oil refineries]] and distributors to ensure that the mix of fuel they sell in the Californian market meets the established declining targets for [[greenhouse gas]] (GHG) emissions measured in [[carbon dioxide equivalent|CO<sub>2</sub>-equivalent]] [[gram]]s per unit of fuel energy sold for transport purposes. The LCFS directive calls for a reduction of at least 10 percent in the carbon intensity of California's transportation fuels by 2020. These reductions include not only [[tailpipe]] emissions but also all other associated emissions from production, distribution and use of transport fuels within the state. Therefore, California LCFS considers the fuel's [[Life cycle assessment|full life cycle]], also known as the "well to wheels" or "seed to wheels" efficiency of transport fuels.<ref name="TwoBillion"/><ref name="CARB01">{{cite web|url=http://www.arb.ca.gov/fuels/lcfs/lcfs.htm|title=Low-Carbon Fuel Standard Program|publisher=[[California Air Resources Board]]|date=2009-04-14|accessdate=2009-04-23}}</ref> The standard is also aimed to reduce the state’s dependence on petroleum, create a market for clean transportation technology, and stimulate the production and use of alternative, low-carbon fuels in California.<ref name="ARBproposal">{{cite web |url= http://www.arb.ca.gov/regact/2009/lcfs09/lcfsisor1.pdf |format=PDF|title=Proposed Regulation to Implement the Low Carbon Fuel Standard. Volume I: Staff Report: Initial Statement of Reasons|publisher=[[California Air Resources Board]]|date=2009-03-05|accessdate=2009-04-26}}</ref>
The LCFS is a mix of [[command and control regulation]] and [[emissions trading]], as it will use market-based mechanisms that allow providers to choose how they will reduce emissions while responding to consumer demand. Some believe that oil companies could opt for several actions to comply. For example, they state that refiners and producers could improve the efficiency of the refineries and upstream production, or may purchase and blend more low-carbon ethanol into gasoline products, or purchase credits from electric utilities supplying low carbon electrons to electric passenger vehicles, or diversifying and selling low carbon hydrogen for use by vehicles as a product, or any new strategy as the standard is being designed.<ref name="TwoBillion"/><ref name="GovernorPR"/> The [[California Global Warming Solutions Act of 2006]] authorized the establishment of emissions trading in California, with rules to be adopted by 2010, and taking effect no later than January 2012.<ref name="TwoBillion"/>
===Regulatory proceedings===
In accordance to the [[California Global Warming Solutions Act of 2006]] and the Governor's Directive, the [[California Air Resources Board]] is the agency responsible for developing the "Low-Carbon Fuel Standard Program", and it was directed to initiate the regulatory proceedings to establish and implement the LCFS."<ref name="TwoBillion"/><ref name="CARB01"/> CARB identified the LCFS as an early action item with a regulation to be adopted and implemented by 2010.<ref name="CARB01"/> Also Executive Order S-1-07 ordered the [[California Environmental Protection Agency]] to coordinate activities between the [[University of California]], the [[California Energy Commission]] and other state agencies to develop and propose a draft compliance schedule to meet the 2020 target.<ref name="CARB01"/>
As mandated by the Executive Order, a University of California team, led by [[Daniel Sperling]] of [[University of California Davis|UC Davis]] and the late [[Alexander E. Farrell]] ([[University of California Berkeley|UC Berkeley]]), developed two reports that established the technical feasibility of an LCFS, proposed the methodology to calculate the full life cycle GHG emissions from all fuels sold in the state, identified technical and policy issues, and provided a number of specific recommendations, thus providing an initial framework for the development of CARB's LCFS.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.energy.ca.gov/low_carbon_fuel_standard/UC_LCFS_study_Part_1-FINAL.pdf|format=PDF |title=A Low-Carbon Fuel Standard for California - Part 1: Technical Analysis |publisher=[[University of California]] |author=Alexander E. Farrell and Daniel Sperling, Project Directors|date=2007-08-01 |accessdate=2009-04-27}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.energy.ca.gov/low_carbon_fuel_standard/UC_LCFS_study_Part_2-FINAL.pdf |format=PDF|title=A Low-Carbon Fuel Standard for California - Part 2: Policy Analysis |publisher=[[University of California]] |author=Alexander E. Farrell and Daniel Sperling, Project Directors|date=2007-08-01 |accessdate=2009-04-27}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.energy.ca.gov/low_carbon_fuel_standard/2007-08-02_UC-NEWS_RELEASE.PDF |title=UC experts detail new standard for cleaner transportation fuels |publisher=[[University of California]] |author=Press Release |date=2007-08-02 |accessdate=2009-04-27}}</ref> This study was presented by Governor Schwarzenegger in May 2007<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.sfgate.com/cgi-bin/article.cgi?file=/c/a/2007/05/18/MNGR2PTFOD1.DTL&type=printable |title=Governor to detail plans to curb fuel emissions |publisher=[[San Francisco Chronicle]] |date=2007-05-18 |accessdate=2009-04-26 | first=Robert | last=Collier}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.sfgate.com/cgi-bin/article.cgi?f=/c/a/2007/05/18/EDGKOP3EFJ1.DTL&hw=Getting+the+Carbon+Out&sn=001&sc=1000 |title=Getting the carbon out |publisher=[[San Francisco Chronicle]] |author=Alex Farrell and Daniel Sperling |date=2007-05-18 |accessdate=2009-04-26}}</ref> and they were the backbone of CARB's initial efforts to develop the LCFS, even though not all of the specific recommendations were incorporated in the final LCFS staff's proposed regulation.<ref name="ARBproposal"/>
====Public consultation process==== During 2008 and until the April 2009 LCFS ruling, CARB published in its website all technical reports prepared by its staff and collaborators regarding the definition and calculations related to the proposed LCFS regulation, conducted 16 public workshops, and also submitted its studies for external peer review.<ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.arb.ca.gov/fuels/lcfs/lcfs.htm |title=Low Carbon Fuel Standard Program |publisher=[[California Air Resources Board]] |accessdate=2009-04-28}}'' See activities listed throughout the page with links to the reports, and records of public activities''.</ref> Before the April 23, 2009 ruling, the Board held a 45-day public hearing that received 229 comments, 21 of which were presented during the Board Hearing.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.arb.ca.gov/lispub/comm/bccommlog.php?listname=lcfs09|title=Comment Log for Low Carbon Fuel Standard (LCFS09) |publisher=[[California Air Resources Board]] |accessdate=2009-04-28}} ''All letters and attachments are posted for public view of this site''.</ref>
====Controversy about indirect land use impacts====
Among relevant and controversial comments submitted to CARB as public letters, on June 24, 2008, a group of 27 scientists and researchers from a number of universities and national laboratories, expressed their concerns arguing that there "''is not enough hard empirical data to base any sound policy regulation in regards to the indirect impacts of renewable biofuels production. The field is relative new, especially when compared to the vast knowledge base present in fossil fuel production, and the limited analyses are driven by assumptions that sometimes lack robust empirical validation''."<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.bioenergywiki.net/images/7/7b/DOE_letter.pdf |format=PDF |title= Public letter to Mary D. Nichols, Chairman California Air Resources Board|publisher=BioenergyWiki |date=2008-06-24 |accessdate=2009-04-28}}</ref><ref name="GCC08"/> With a similar opposing position, on October 23, 2008, a letter submitted to CARB by the New Fuels Alliance, representing more than two-dozen advanced biofuel companies, researchers and investors, questioned the Board intention to include [[ILUC|indirect land use change]] (ILUC).<ref name="GCC08">{{cite web |url=http://www.greencarcongress.com/2008/10/biofuel-compani.html |title=Biofuel Companies Question ARB’s Inclusion of Indirect Effects in Low Carbon Fuel Standard |publisher=[[Green Car Congress]] |date=2008-10-24 |accessdate=2009-04-28}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.newfuelsalliance.org/NFA%20ARB%20ILUC%20Press%20Release%20Final.pdf |format=PDF |title=Leading Advanced Biofuel Companies, Researchers, Investors Call on Air Resources Board to Reconsider Draft Low Carbon Fuel Regulations |publisher=New Fuels Alliance |date=2008-10-23 |accessdate=2009-04-26}}</ref> In another public letter just before the ruling meeting, more than 170 scientists and economists sent a letter to CARB, urging it to account for GHG emissions from indirect land use change for biofuels and all other transportation fuels. They argued that ''"...there are uncertainties inherent in estimating the magnitude of indirect land use emissions from biofuels, but assigning a value of zero is clearly not supported by the science."''<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.ucsusa.org/assets/documents/clean_vehicles/call_to_action_biofuels_and_land_use_change.pdf |format=PDF |title=Public letter to Mary D. Nichols, Chairman California Air Resources Board |publisher=[[Union of Concerned Scientists]] |date=2009-04-21 |accessdate=2009-04-26}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.greencarcongress.com/2009/04/usc-lcfs-20090421.html|title=Group of Scientists and Economists Urge Inclusion of Indirect Land Use Change Effects for Biofuels and All Transportation Fuels in California LCFS |publisher=Green Car Congress |date=2009-04-21 |accessdate=2009-04-28}}</ref>
===2009 Ruling===
On April 23, 2009, CARB approved the specific rules and carbon intensity reference values for the LCFS that will go into effect on January 1, 2011.<ref name="SFG042409">{{cite news |url=http://www.sfgate.com/cgi-bin/article.cgi?f=/c/a/2009/04/23/BABA1782HB.DTL&type=green&tsp=1 |title=Air Resources Board moves to cut carbon use |publisher=[[San Francisco Chronicle]] |author=Wyatt Buchanan |date=2009-04-24 |accessdate=2009-04-25}}</ref><ref name="NYT042409">{{cite news |url=https://query.nytimes.com/gst/fullpage.html?res=9805E6DB113CF937A15757C0A96F9C8B63 |title=California: Low-Carbon-Fuels Mandate |publisher=[[New York Times]] |author=[[The Associated Press]]|date=2009-04-24 |accessdate=2009-05-21}}</ref> The technical proposal was approved without modifications by a 9-1 vote, to set the 2020 maximum carbon intensity reference value for gasoline to 86 grams of [[carbon dioxide equivalent]] released per [[megajoule]] of energy produced.<ref name="UNICA01">{{cite news|url=http://world-wire.com/news/0904230003.html |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090426072816/http://world-wire.com/news/0904230003.html |dead-url=yes |archive-date=2009-04-26 |title=Sugarcane Ethanol Passes Critical Test in California |publisher=World-Wire |author=[[UNICA, Brazil|UNICA]] Press release |date=2009-04-24 |accessdate=2009-04-25 }}</ref> One standard was established for gasoline and the alternative fuels that can replace it, and a second similar standard is set for diesel fuel and its replacements.<ref name ="CARBruleB">{{cite web|url=http://www.arb.ca.gov/fuels/lcfs/lcfs_att_b_mod.pdf |format=pdf|title=Draft Attachment B: Public Hearing to Consider Adoption of a Proposed Regulation to Implement the Low Carbon Fuel Standard - Staff’s Suggested Modifications to the Original Proposal|date=2003-04-23|publisher=CARB|accessdate=2009-04-30}}</ref> The regulation is based on an average declining standard of [[carbon intensity]] that is expected to achieve 16 million metric tons of greenhouse gas emission reductions by 2020.<ref name="CARBpr">{{cite news|url=http://www.arb.ca.gov/newsrel/nr042309b.htm |title=California Adopts Low Carbon Fuel Standard |publisher=[[California Air Resources Board]] Press release |date=2009-04-23 |accessdate=2009-04-25 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090426085637/http://www.arb.ca.gov/newsrel/nr042309b.htm |archivedate=April 26, 2009 }}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url=http://news.cnet.com/8301-11128_3-10226803-54.html |title=Calif. sets low-carbon standard for cars |publisher=CNetNews |author=Jonathan Skillings |date=2009-04-24 |accessdate=2009-04-27}}</ref> CARB expects the new generation of fuels to come from the development of technology that uses [[cellulosic ethanol]] from [[algae]], wood, agricultural waste such as [[straw]] and [[switchgrass]], and also [[natural gas]] from municipal solid waste. They also expect the standard to drive the availability of [[plug-in hybrid]], [[electric car|battery electric]] and [[fuel-cell]] powered cars while promoting investment in infrastructure for electric charging stations and hydrogen fueling stations.<ref name= "CARBpr"/>

The CARB staff is also expected to report back to the Board on indirect impacts of other fuel pathways before the commencement of the standard in 2011.<ref name="CNN0409">{{cite news|url=http://money.cnn.com/2009/04/23/news/economy/california.reut/index.htm |title=California adopts first-ever low-carbon fuel rule |publisher=[[CNN News]] |date=2009-04-23 |accessdate=2009-04-28 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090427132230/http://money.cnn.com/2009/04/23/news/economy/california.reut/index.htm |archivedate=April 27, 2009 |df= }}</ref><ref name="BDigest"/>

The LCFS standards established in CARB's rulemaking will be periodically reviewed. The first formal review will occur by January 1, 2011. Additional reviews are expected to be conducted approximately every three years thereafter, or as necessary. The 2011 review will consider the status of efforts to develop low carbon fuels, the compliance schedule, updated technical information, and provide recommendations on metrics to address the sustainable production of low carbon fuels.<ref name ="CARBruleB"/>
According to CARB's ruling, providers of transportation fuels must demonstrate that the mix of fuels they supply meet the LCFS intensity standards for each annual compliance period. They must report all fuels provided and track the fuels’ carbon intensity through a system of "credits" and "deficits." Credits are generated from fuels with lower carbon intensity than the standard. Deficits result from the use of fuels with higher carbon intensity than the standard. A fuel provider meets its compliance obligation by ensuring that amount of credits it earns (or otherwise acquires from another party) is equal to, or greater than, the deficits it has incurred. Credits and deficits are generally determined based on the amount of fuel sold, the carbon intensity of the fuel, and the efficiency by which a vehicle converts the fuel into usable energy. Credits may be banked and traded within the LCFS market to meet obligations.<ref name="ARBproposal"/>
Two "lookup tables" (similar to the one above) and its carbon intensity values are part of the regulation, one for gasoline and another for diesel. The carbon intensity values can only be amended or expanded by regulatory amendments, and the Board delegated to the Executive Officer the responsibility to conduct the necessary rulemaking hearings and take final action on any amendments, other than amending indirect land-use change values included in the lookup tables.<ref name ="CARBruleB"/>

On July 20, 2009, CARB published a Notice of Public Availability of modified text and availability of additional documents regarding the April 2009 rule making (Resolution 09-31), open for public comment until August 19. The supporting documents and information added to the rule making record include new pathways for [[Liquefied Natural Gas]] (LNG) from several sources, [[Compressed Natural Gas]] (CNG) from dairy digester biogas, [[biodiesel]] produced in California from used cooking oil, renewable diesel produced in California from [[tallow]] (U.S. sourced), and two additional new pathways for [[Ethanol fuel in Brazil|Brazilian sugarcane ethanol]] which reflect best practices already implemented in some regions of the country.<ref name=UNICA0709/><ref name=CARB0809>{{cite web|url=http://www.arb.ca.gov/regact/2009/lcfs09/lcfs09.htm|title=HEARING ACTION AND SUPPLEMENTAL 15-DAY NOTICES - Posted July 20, 2009|publisher=[[California Air Resources Board]]|date=2009-07-20|accessdate=2009-07-31}}</ref>
The two additional scenarios for sugarcane ethanol were requested by the Board in order to account for improved harvesting practices and the export of electricity from sugarcane ethanol plants in Brazil using energy from [[bagasse]].<ref name=ARBsugarcane/><ref name=UNICA0709/><ref name=Biofuels0709/> These two scenarios are not to be considered average for all of Brazilian ethanol but specific cases when such practices are adopted in Brazil. Scenario 1 considers mechanized harvesting of cane which is gradually replacing the traditional practice of burning straw before harvesting cane, and the sale of electricity (co-generated) from power plants that are capable of exporting additional energy beyond that required for processing in the plant (co-product credit). Scenario 2 only considers the export of electricity (co-product) from power plants capable of producing the additional electricity for export. The assumptions or values for the baseline pathway published in February 2009 are the same, including the estimates of [[ILUC|indirect land use change]] for all Brazilian sugarcane scenarios.<ref name=ARBsugarcane/><ref name=UNICA0709/>
On December 2009 the [[Renewable Fuels Association]] (RFA) and [[Growth Energy]], two U.S. ethanol lobbying groups, filed a lawsuit in the Federal District Court in Fresno, California, challenging the constitutionality of the California Low Carbon Fuel Standard (LCFS). The two organizations are arguing that the LCFS violates both the [[Supremacy Clause]] and the [[Commerce Clause]] of the [[US Constitution]], and "''jeopardizes the nationwide market for ethanol''."<ref name=WSJ1209>{{cite news|url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/SB126169282611304857|title=Ethanol Groups Sue California Over Low-Carbon Rule|publisher=[[Wall Street Journal]]|date=2009-12-24|accessdate=2009-12-29 | first=Stephen | last=Power}}</ref><ref name=GCC1209>{{cite web|url=http://www.greencarcongress.com/2009/12/rfa-lcfs-20091225.html#more|title=Ethanol Groups File Suit Challenging Constitutionality of California Low Carbon Fuel Standard|publisher=[[Green Car Congress]]|date=2009-12-25|accessdate=2009-12-29}}</ref> In a press release both association announced that “''If the United States is going to have a low carbon fuel standard, it must be based on sound science and it must be consistent with the U.S. Constitution''..." and that "''One state cannot dictate policy for all the others, yet that is precisely what California has aimed to do through a poorly conceived and, frankly, unconstitutional LCFS''.”<ref>{{cite web|url=http://renewablefuelsassociation.cmail1.com/T/ViewEmail/y/9E510C2CBC9CF893/968C17640481D3A09A8E73400EDACAB4|title=Ethanol Groups Challenge Constitutionality of California LCFS|publisher=[[Renewable Fuels Association]]|date=2009-12-24|accessdate=2009-12-29}}</ref> Additional lawsuits against the California regulation were filed by refiners and truckers including Rocky Mountain Farmers Union; Redwood County Minnesota Corn and Soybean Growers; Penny Newman Grain, Inc.; Red Nederend; Fresno County Farm Bureau; Nisei Farmers League; California Dairy Campaign; [[National Petrochemical and Refiners Association]]; [[American Trucking Associations]]; Center for North American Energy Security; and the Consumer Energy Alliance.<ref name=CalBlocked1>{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2011/12/30/us/judge-blocks-californias-low-carbon-fuel-standard.html?_r=1&scp=1&sq=California%20fuel%20standard&st=cse|title=Judge Blocks a California Fuel Regulation|author=Felicity Barringer|work=[[The New York Times]]|date=2011-12-29|accessdate=2011-12-31}}</ref><ref name=CalBlocked2>{{cite web|url=http://www.greencarcongress.com/2011/12/lcfs-20111231.html|title=California ARB withholding enforcement of LCFS post Federal Court injunction; appealing and seeking stay of injunction; Judge O’Neill’s 3 rulings|publisher=[[Green Car Congress]]|date=2011-12-31|accessdate=2012-01-02}}</ref>
In December 2011 a federal judge granted a preliminary injunction against the implementation of California's LCFS. In three separate rulings the judge rejected CARB's defense as he concluded that the state that the state acted unconstitutionally and the regulation ''“impermissibly treads into the province and powers of our federal government, reaches beyond its boundaries to regulate activity wholly outside of its borders.”'' CARB announced it intends to appeal the decision. The Ninth Circuit Court of Appeals issued a stay of the injunction on 23 April 2012 during the tendency of the litigation. In other words, the challenge to the constitutionality of the LCFS continues, but until it is resolved there is no bar on the CARB continuing to enforce the LCFS. (While the stay did not specifically authorize a return to the LCFS, CARB argued in its briefs before the Court that a stay would "permit the LCFS to go back into effect as though the injunction had never been issued". That is the approach currently taken by CARB and it continues to refine carbon intensity standards and applicability).<ref>http://www.arb.ca.gov/fuels/lcfs/072413lcfs-rep-adv.pdf</ref>
In 2011, a provision was added to the LCFS that allows refiners to receive credits for the deployment of innovative crude production technologies, such as carbon capture and sequestration or solar steam generation.<ref>http://www.theicct.org/blogs/staff/carb-looks-innovative-methods-reduce-upstream-oil-production-emissions</ref> [[Solar thermal enhanced oil recovery]] is a form of [[enhanced oil recovery]] (EOR), which is key to harvesting California’s heavy crude.<ref>http://energy.gov/fe/science-innovation/oil-gas/enhanced-oil-recovery</ref> Currently, California uses EOR to help produce about 60% of its crude output.<ref>http://blogs.platts.com/2014/05/30/solar-eor-california-lcfs/</ref> By using solar power instead of natural gas to create steam for EOR, solar steam generation reduces the amount of emissions produced during oil extraction, thus lowering the overall carbon intensity of crude. California currently has two solar EOR projects in operation, one in McKittrick, operated by LINN Energy (formerly Berry Petroleum) using enclosed trough technology from [[GlassPoint Solar]], and another in Coalinga operated by [[Chevron Corporation]] using [[BrightSource Energy]] power tower technology.
CARB is currently considering an amendment to allow upstream operators to receive credits for deploying innovative crude production technologies.<ref>http://www.arb.ca.gov/fuels/lcfs/lcfs_meetings/041814crudehandout.pdf</ref>
In 2015, California's LCFS was re-adopted in order to address some of the issues in the original proposed standard. A number of the changes were made, including updated crude provisions, a new model used to be used to calculate carbon intensity, the establishment of a "Credit Clearance" process that would take effect at the end of the year should the LCFS credit market become too competitive, and other provisions.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.arb.ca.gov/fuels/lcfs/lcfs-background.htm|title=Low Carbon Fuel Standard Program Background|last=|first=|date=|website=|access-date=}}</ref>
In May 2016, the Seneca Solar Project became the first facility to start earning LCFS credits. Located in the North Midway Sunset oil field in Taft, Kern County, California, this facility met the threshold of 0.10gCO2/ MJ carbon intensity (CI) reduction.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.arb.ca.gov/fuels/lcfs/crude-oil/innovative-crude/2016-0804_seneca-application.pdf|title=Seneca Solar Project|last=|first=|date=|website=|access-date=}}</ref>
Shortly after that, in August 2016, the SB 32 was passed, which changed the target for green house gas (GHG) reduction to 40% below the levels in 1990, to be achieved by 2030.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.manatt.com/Insights/Newsletters/Climate-Change/Move-Over-AB-32,-Here-Comes-SB-32!-(and-AB-197)|title=SB 32 and AB 197|last=|first=|date=|website=|access-date=}}</ref> It is anticipated that this will lead to the tightening of LCFS standards from 2020 all the way through 2030.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.arb.ca.gov/fuels/lcfs/lcfs_meetings/080717conceptpaper.pdf|title=Low Carbon Fuel Standard 2018 Amendments|last=|first=|date=|website=|access-date=}}</ref>
In November 2017, GlassPoint announced a partnership with [[Aera Energy]] to bring its enclosed trough technology to the [[South Belridge Oil Field]], near [[Bakersfield, California]]. When done, the facility will be California’s largest solar EOR field. It is projected to produce approximately 12 million barrels of steam per year through a 850MW thermal solar steam generator. It will also cut carbon emissions from the facility by 376,000 metric tons per year.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://mailchi.mp/glasspoint/belridge-solar-announcement|title=GlassPoint Announces Belridge Solar Project|last=|first=|date=|website=|access-date=}}</ref>
==US National Low-Carbon Fuel Standard== Using California's LCFS as a model, several bills have been presented to establish a national low-carbon fuel standards at the federal level.
===2007===
[[United States Senate|Senator]]s [[Barbara Boxer]], [[Dianne Feinstein]], and future President [[Barack Obama]] introduced in 2007 competing bills with varying versions of California's LCFS.<ref name="SFGate0507">{{cite news |url=http://www.sfgate.com/cgi-bin/article.cgi?file=/c/a/2007/05/18/MNGR2PTFOD1.DTL&type=printable|title=Governor to detail plans to curb fuel emissions |publisher=[[San Francisco Chronicle]] |author=Robert Collier |date=2007-05-18 |accessdate=2009-04-24 }}</ref>
*In March 2007, Senator Dianne Feinstein sponsored the "Clean Fuels and Vehicles Bill", which would have reduced emissions from motor vehicle fuels by 10 percent below projected levels by 2030, and would have required fuel suppliers to increase the percentage of low-carbon fuels – biodiesel, E-85 (made with cellulosic ethanol), hydrogen, electricity, and others – in the motor vehicle fuel supply.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://feinstein.senate.gov/public/index.cfm?ContentRecord_id=a4499663-9559-b897-f40b-7b3ba9c94fcd&FuseAction=NewsRoom.PressReleases |title=Senators Feinstein, Collins and Snowe Introduce Measure to Reduce Carbon Dioxide Emissions from the Use of Motor Vehicles |publisher= Dianne Feinstein Press Release|date=2007-03-30 |accessdate=2009-04-24}}</ref> *California Senator Barbara Boxer presented on May 3, 2007 the "Advanced Clean Fuels Act of 2007". This bill was an amendment to the [[United States Clean Air Act|Clean Air Act]] to promote the use of advanced clean fuels that help reduce air and water pollution and protect the environment.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.govtrack.us/congress/bill.xpd?bill=s110-1297|title=1297: Advanced Clean Fuels Act of 2007|publisher=Govtrackus|accessdate=2009-04-24}}</ref> *Then Senator Obama introduced his bill on May 7, 2007. The "National Low Carbon Fuel Standard Act of 2007" would have required fuel refineries to reduce the lifecycle greenhouse gas emissions of the transportation fuels sold in the U.S. by 5 percent in 2015 and 10 percent in 2020.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.renewableenergyworld.com/rea/news/article/2007/05/obama-introduces-national-low-carbon-fuel-standard-48427 |title=Obama Introduces National Low-Carbon Fuel Standard |publisher=Renweable Energy World |date=2007-05-17 |accessdate=2009-04-24 }}</ref>
===2009=== In March 2009, the [[American Clean Energy and Security Act|Waxman-Markey Climate Bill]] was introduced in the [[U.S. House Committee on Energy and Commerce]], and it has been praised by top [[Obama Administration]] officials.<ref name="NYT042209">{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/gwire/2009/04/22/22greenwire-obama-admin-portrays-house-emissions-bill-as-e-10632.html?scp=1&sq=Obama%20admin%20House%20climate%20bill%20economic%20boon&st=cse|title=California Weighs Low-Carbon Fuel Standard|author=Kate Galbraith |publisher=[[New York Times]]|date=2009-04-23|accessdate=2009-04-24}}</ref><ref name="NYT042309">{{cite news|url=http://greeninc.blogs.nytimes.com/2009/04/23/california-weighs-low-carbon-fuel-standard/|title=Obama admin portrays House climate bill as economic boon|author=Darren Samulsohn |publisher=[[New York Times]]|date=2009-04-22|accessdate=2009-04-24}}</ref> The bill requires a slightly higher targets for reductions in emissions of [[carbon dioxide]], [[methane]], and other [[greenhouse gas]]es than those proposed by [[President of the United States|President]] [[Barack Obama]]. The bill proposed a 20-percent emissions reduction from 2005 levels by 2020 (Obama had proposed a 14 percent reduction by 2020). Both plans aim to reduce emissions by about 80 percent by 2050. The Climate Change Bill was approved by the [[U.S. House of Representatives]] on June 26, 2009. As approved, emissions would be cut 17 percent from 2005 levels by 2020, and 83 percent by 2050.<ref name=Economist07/><ref name=NYT07/>
===EPA Renewable Fuel Standard=== The [[Energy Independence and Security Act of 2007]] (EISA) established new renewable fuel categories and eligibility requirements, setting mandatory [[life cycle assessment|life cycle]] [[greenhouse gas]] emissions thresholds for renewable fuel categories, as compared to those of average petroleum fuels used in 2005.<ref name=EPAdraft>{{cite web |url=http://www.epa.gov/otaq/renewablefuels/420f09024.pdf|format=PDF |title=EPA Lifecycle Analysis of Greenhouse Gas Emissions from Renewable Fuels - Technical Highlights |publisher= |date= |accessdate=2009-06-07}} ''See Table 1''.</ref><ref name=EPA0509>{{cite web|url=http://www.epa.gov/OMS/renewablefuels/420f09023.htm|title=EPA Proposes New Regulations for the National Renewable Fuel Standard Program for 2010 and Beyond|publisher=[[US Environmental Protection Agency]] |date=2009-05-05 |accessdate=2009-06-16}}</ref> EISA definition of life cycle GHG emissions explicitly mandated the [[U.S. Environmental Protection Agency]] (EPA) to include "''direct emissions and significant indirect emissions such as significant emissions from land use changes''."<ref name=EPAdraft/><ref name=EPA0509/><ref name=GCC0509>{{cite web|url=http://www.greencarcongress.com/2009/05/epa-nprm-20090505.html|title=EPA Proposes New Regulations for Renewable Fuel Standard to Implement Requirements of EISA; GHG Reduction and Indirect Land Use Change Effects Included|publisher=[[Green Car Congress]] |date=2009-05-05|accessdate=2009-06-16}}</ref>
On May 5, 2009 the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) released its [[notice of proposed rulemaking]] for implementation of the 2007 modification of the [[Renewable Fuel Standard]] (RFS).<ref name=GCC0509/><ref name=EPAproposal>{{cite web |url=http://www.epa.gov/otaq/renewablefuels/#regulations |title=Renewable Fuel Standard Program (RFS2): Notice of Proposed Rulemaking |publisher=US Environmental Protection Agency |date=2009-05-05 |accessdate=2009-05-06}}</ref> The draft of the regulations was released for public comment during a 60-day period. EPA's proposed regulations also included the [[carbon footprint]] from [[ILUC|indirect land-use changes]], which, as CARB's ruling, caused controversy among ethanol producers.<ref name="LAT0609">{{cite news|url=http://www.latimes.com/news/nationworld/nation/la-na-corn-ethanol6-2009may06,0,2321568.story |title=New standards could cut tax breaks for corn-based ethanol |publisher=[[Los Angeles Times]] |date=2009-05-06 |accessdate=2009-05-06 |author= Jim Tankersley}}</ref><ref name="Guardian0609">{{cite news |url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2009/may/06/obama-ethanol-green-biofuel|title=Barack Obama's $1.8bn vision of greener biofuel|author= Suzanne Goldenberg |publisher=[[The Guardian]] |date=2009-05-06 |accessdate=2009-05-06 | location=London}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2009/05/05/AR2009050503731.html?hpid%3Dmoreheadlines&sub=AR|title=EPA Proposes Changes To Biofuel Regulations |publisher=[[The Washington Post]] |author= Steven Mufson and Juliet Eilperin |date=2009-05-06 |accessdate=2009-05-06}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://earth2tech.com/2009/05/05/corn-ethanol-crew-cries-foul-over-epa-emissions-ruling/ |title=Corn Ethanol Crew Cries Foul Over EPA Emissions Ruling |publisher=earth2tech.com |author= Jennifer Kho |date=2009-05-05 |accessdate=2009-05-06}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://triangle.bizjournals.com/triangle/prnewswire/press_releases/national/California/2009/05/05/SPTU003 |title=Sugarcane Ethanol Industry Eager to Implement U.S. Renewable Fuel Standard |publisher=National Press Release |author=[[UNICA, Brazil|UNICA]] Press Release|date=2009-05-05 |accessdate=2009-05-06}}</ref> On the same day, President [[Barack Obama]] signed a [[Presidential Directive]] with the aim to advance biofuels research and improve their commercialization. The Directive established a Biofuels Interagency Working Group which has the mandate to come up with policy ideas for increasing investment in next-generation fuels, such as cellulosic ethanol, and for reducing the environmental footprint of growing biofuels crops, particularly corn-based ethanol.<ref name="LAT0609"/><ref name="WH0509">{{cite web|url=http://www.whitehouse.gov/the_press_office/President-Obama-Announces-Steps-to-Support-Sustainable-Energy-Options/|publisher=[[The White House]]|title=President Obama Announces Steps to Support Sustainable Energy Options, Departments of Agriculture and Energy, Environmental Protection Agency to Lead Efforts|date=2009-05-05|accessdate=2009-05-05|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090506233214/http://www.whitehouse.gov/the_press_office/President-Obama-Announces-Steps-to-Support-Sustainable-Energy-Options/|archivedate=2009-05-06|df=}}</ref><ref name="NYT0509">{{cite news|url=http://greeninc.blogs.nytimes.com/2009/05/05/white-house-steps-up-support-for-biofuels/ |title=White House Steps Up Support for Biofuels |publisher=[[New York Times]] |date=2009-05-05 |accessdate=2009-05-05 |author= Matthew L. Wald}}</ref><ref name="Sciam0509">{{cite news|url=http://www.scientificamerican.com/article.cfm?id=obama-administration-pushes-biofuels |title=Obama Administration Prepares to Push Biofuels |publisher=[[Scientific American]] |date=2009-05-05 |accessdate=2009-05-05 |author= Ben Geman}}</ref>
An amendment was introduced in the [[House Appropriations Committee]] during the discussion of the fiscal 2010 Interior and Environment spending bill, aimed to prohibit EPA to consider indirect land-use changes in the RFS2 ruling for five years. This amendment was rejected on June 18, 2009 by a 30 to 29 vote.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/gwire/2009/06/19/19greenwire-farm-interests-use-epa-spending-bill-to-fight-85048.html |title=Farm Interests Use EPA Spending Bill to Fight Climate Regs|publisher=[[New York Times]]|date=2009-06-19 |accessdate=2009-06-26 | first1=Robin | last1=Bravender | first2=Ben | last2=Geman | first3=Taryn | last3=Luntz}}</ref> A similar amendment to the [[American Clean Energy and Security Act|Waxman-Markey Climate Bill]] was introduced in the [[U.S. House Committee on Energy and Commerce]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.greencarcongress.com/2009/06/peterson-20090626.html|title=Compromise Amendment to Waxman-Markey Bill Prohibits EPA From Using Indirect Land Use Change Metrics on Biofuels for 5 Years While National Academies Research the Issue|publisher=[[Green Car Congress]]|date=2009-06-26 |accessdate=2009-06-26}}</ref> The Climate Bill was approved by the [[U.S. House of Representatives]] with a vote of 219 to 212, and included a mandate for EPA to exclude any estimation of international indirect land use changes due to biofuels for a five-year period for the purposes of the RFS2. During this period, more research is to be conducted to develop more reliable models and methodologies for estimating ILUC.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://biofuelsdigest.com/blog2/2009/06/29/climate-change-bill-passes-with-five-year-punt-on-indirect-land-use-change/trackback/ |title=Climate change bill passes, with five-year punt on indirect land use change |publisher=Biofuels Digest |author=Jim Lane |date=2009-06-29 |accessdate=2009-07-05 }}{{dead link|date=January 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://industry.bnet.com/energy/10001543/climate-change-bill-passes-on-razor-thin-margin-tougher-battle-awaits-in-senate/ |title=Climate Change Bill Passes on Razor-Thin Margin, Tougher Battle Lies Ahead |publisher=BNET Energy |author=Kirsten Korosec |date=2009-06-27 |accessdate=2009-07-05}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://renewablefuelsassociation.cmail1.com/T/ViewEmail/y/C192A849C6FF6842 |title= House passes historic climate bill |publisher=[[Renewable Fuels Association]]|date=2009-06-26 |accessdate=2009-07-05}}</ref> By 2010 the bill is awaiting approval by the [[U.S. Senate]].<ref name=Economist07>{{cite news |url=http://www.economist.com/world/unitedstates/displaystory.cfm?story_id=13952934 |title=A squeaker, with more to come |publisher=[[The Economist]]|date=2009-07-02 |accessdate=2009-07-05}}</ref><ref name=NYT07>{{cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2009/07/01/us/politics/01climate.html?pagewanted=1&_r=3&ref=science |title=With Something for Everyone, Climate Bill Passed |publisher=[[New York Times]] |author=John M. Broder |date=2009-06-30 |accessdate=2009-07-05}}</ref> {| class="wikitable" style="float: right; margin-left: 10px" ! colspan="3" align=center style="background-color: #ABCDEF;" |[[Energy Independence and Security Act of 2007|EISA]] Standards for 2010<ref name=EPA2010/> |- ! style="background-color: #ABCDEF;" |Fuel Category|| style="background-color: #ABCDEF;" |<small>Percentage of <br>Fuel Required <br>to be Renewable </small> || style="background-color: #ABCDEF;" |<small>Volume of <br>Renewable Fuel<br>(in billion gal)</small> |- |Cellulosic biofuel||<center>0.004%</center>||<center>0.0065</center> |- |Biomass-based diesel||<center>1.10%<sup>(1)</sup></center>||<center>1.15<sup>(1)</sup></center> |- |Total Advanced biofuel ||<center>0.61% </center>||<center>0.95</center> |- |Renewable fuel ||<center>8.25%</center>||<center>12.95</center> |- | colspan="3" |<small>Notes: (1) Combined 2009/2010 biomass-based diesel volumes applied in 2010.</small> |} On February 3, 2010, EPA issued its final rule regarding the expanded Renewable Fuel Standard (RFS2) for 2010 and beyond.<ref name=EPArule2010>{{cite web|url=http://www.epa.gov/OMS/renewablefuels/|title=Renewable Fuel Standard Program (RFS2): Final Rule|publisher=[[U.S. Environmental Protection Agency]]|date=2010-02-03|accessdate=2010-02-09}}</ref> The final rule revises the annual renewable fuel standards, and the required renewable fuel volume continues to increase reaching 36 billion gallons (136.3 billion liters) by 2022. For 2010, EISA set a total renewable fuel standard of 12.95 billion gallons (49.0 billion liters). This total volume, presented as a fraction of a refiner's or importer's gasoline and diesel volume, must be renewable fuel. The final 2010 standards set by EPA are shown in the table in the right side.<ref name=EPA2010/>
As mandated by law, and in order to establish the fuel category for each biofuel, EPA included in its modeling direct emissions and significant indirect emissions such as [[ILUC|emissions from land use changes]] related to the full lifecycle. EPA's modeling of specific fuel pathways incorporated comments received through the third-party peer review process, and data and information from new studies and public comments. EPA's analysis determined that both [[Ethanol fuel in the United States|ethanol produced from corn starch]] and [[Butanol fuel|biobutanol]] from corn starch comply with the 20% GHG emission reduction threshold required to classify as a renewable fuel.<ref name=EPA2010/> EISA [[Grandfather clause|grandfathered]] existing U.S. corn ethanol plants, and only requires the 20% reduction in life cycle GHG emissions for any renewable fuel produced at new facilities that commenced construction after December 19, 2007.<ref name=EPAdraft/><ref name=EPA0509/><ref name=GCC0509/>
EPA also determined that [[Ethanol fuel in Brazil|ethanol produced from sugarcane]], both in [[Brazil]] and [[Caribbean Basin Initiative]] countries, complies with the applicable 50% GHG reduction threshold for the advanced fuel category. Both [[Green diesel|diesel produced from algal oils]] and [[biodiesel]] from soy oil and renewable diesel from waste oils, fats, and greases complies with the 50% GHG threshold for the biomass-based diesel category. [[Cellulosic ethanol]] and cellulosic diesel (based on currently modeled pathways) comply with the 60% GHG reduction threshold applicable to cellulosic biofuels.<ref name=EPA2010>{{cite web|url=http://www.epa.gov/OMS/renewablefuels/420f10007.htm#7|title=Greenhouse Gas Reduction Thresholds|publisher=[[U.S. Environmental Protection Agency]]|date=2010-02-03|accessdate=2010-02-09}}</ref>

UNICA, a Brazilian ethanol producers association, welcomed the ruling and commented that they hope the classification of Brazilian sugarcane ethanol as an advanced biofuel will contribute to influence those who seek to lift the trade barriers imposed against clean energy, both in the U.S. and the rest of the world.<ref name=UNICA022010>{{cite In the case of corn-based ethanol, EPA said that manufacturers would need to use “advanced efficient technologies” during production to meet RSF2 limits.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2010/02/12/business/energy-environment/12biofuel.html|title=Questions About Biofuels' Environmental Costs Could Alter Europe's Policies|publisher=[[New York Times]]|author=James Kanter|date=2010-02-11|accessdate=2010-02-14}}</ref> The U.S. [[Renewable Fuels Association]] also welcomed the ruling, as ethanol producers "''require stable federal policy that provides them the market assurances they need to commercialize new technologies.''" However, they complained that "''EPA continues to rely on oft-challenged and unproven theories such as international indirect land use change to penalize U.S. biofuels to the advantage of imported ethanol and petroleum.''"<ref name=RFA012010>{{cite web|url=http://renewablefuelsassociation.cmail1.com/T/ViewEmail/y/78B3C6C380747C63|title=RFS Rules "Workable" - ILUC Inclusion Still Problematic|publisher=[[Renewable Fuels Association]]|date=2010-02-03|accessdate=2010-02-14}}</ref>
==Other U.S. regional proposals==
Eleven U.S. [[Northeastern United States|Northeast]] and [[Mid-Atlantic States|Mid-Atlantic]] states have committed to analyzing a single low-carbon fuel standard for the entire region, driving commercialization and creating a larger market for fuels with low [[carbon intensity]]. The standard is aimed to reduce greenhouse gas emissions from fuels for vehicles and other uses, including fuel used for heating buildings, industrial processes, and electricity generation.<ref name="SciAm"/><ref name="ARBproposal"/><ref name="11States01"/><ref name="11States02">{{cite web |url=http://www.mass.gov/Eoeea/docs/pr_lcfs_attach.pdf|format=PDF |title=Letter of Intent: NortheastlMid-Atiantic States Low Carbon Fuel Standard Program |publisher=Massachusetts Government |date= 2008-12-31|accessdate=2009-04-30}}</ref><ref name="11States03"/> Ten of these states are members of the [[Regional Greenhouse Gas Initiative]] (RGGI).<ref name="11States03">{{cite web |url=http://www.greencarcongress.com/2009/01/eleven-northeas.html |title=Eleven Northeast and Mid-Atlantic States to Develop Regional Low Carbon Fuel Standard |publisher=Green Car Congress |date=2009-01-06 |accessdate=2009-04-30}}</ref> [[California Air Resources Board]] (CARB) staff has been coordinating with representatives of these States.<ref name="ARBproposal"/> The states developing a regional LCFS are [[Connecticut]], [[Delaware]], [[Maine]], [[Maryland]], [[Massachusetts]], [[New Hampshire]], [[New Jersey]], [[New York (state)|New York]], [[Pennsylvania]], [[Rhode Island]], and [[Vermont]].<ref name="ARBproposal"/><ref name="11States01">{{cite news |url=http://green.foxnews.com/2009/01/09/eleven-eastern-states-agree-to-low-carbon-standard/ |title=Eleven Eastern States Agree to Low Carbon Standard |publisher=FoxNews.com |author=The Associated Press|date=2009-01-09 |accessdate=2009-04-30}}</ref>
A Memorandum of Understanding concerning the development of the regional low carbon fuel standard program was signed by the Governors of each State on December 30, 2009, committing the states to an economic analysis of the program, consultation with stakeholders before ruling, and a draft model rule by early 2011.<ref name="ARBproposal"/><ref name="11States03"/><ref>[http://www.nescaum.org/documents/lcfs-mou-govs-final.pdf/ Memorandum of Understanding about the regional LCFS program signed by the Governors of each State on December 30, 2009]</ref>
==British Columbia Low-Carbon Fuel Requirements== The [[Legislative Assembly of British Columbia]], [[Canada]], approved in April 2008 the [[Renewable and Low Carbon Fuel Requirements Act]], which mandates fuel suppliers in B.C. to sell gasoline and diesel containing 5% and 4% percent renewable fuels,<ref>http://www.empr.gov.bc.ca/RET/RLCFRR/Pages/default.aspx</ref> respectively, by 2010, and allows the provincial government to set thresholds for the [[carbon intensity]] of fuels, taking into account their entire [[carbon footprint]].<ref name="Vancouver08">{{cite news |url=http://www2.canada.com/vancouversun/news/business/story.html?id=23e7f256-4ebc-4468-974a-c4219d78b13b&p=1 |title=Government brings in low-carbon fuel bill |publisher=[[The Vancouver Sun]] |author=Derrick Penner |date=2008-04-02 |accessdate=2009-04-26 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120314153812/http://www2.canada.com/vancouversun/news/business/story.html?id=23e7f256-4ebc-4468-974a-c4219d78b13b&p=1 |archivedate=2012-03-14 |df= }}</ref><ref name="Bill 16">{{cite news |url=http://www.leg.bc.ca/38th4th/amend/gov16-2.htm#section6 |title= Bill 16 - 2008: Greenhouse Gas Reduction (Renewable and Low Carbon Fuel Requirements) Act|publisher= [[Legislative Assembly of British Columbia]] |date=2008-04-17 |accessdate=2009-04-26}}</ref> The RLCFR Act also provides flexibility for regulated fuel suppliers to meet their obligations as they may receive notional transfers of renewable fuels and of attributable greenhouse gas emissions.<ref name="Bill 16"/><ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.mondaq.com/article.asp?articleid=66514 |title=Canada: Climate Change Law Update: Recent North American Developments - June 2008 |publisher=Mondaq |author=Gray E. Taylor|date=2008-09-22 |accessdate=2009-04-26|display-authors=etal}}</ref>
==Europe==
===Existing regulations=== The EU has mainly acted to mitigate road transport greenhouse emissions mainly through its voluntary agreement on CO2 emissions from cars and subsequently through Regulation 443/2009 which sets mandatory CO2 emission limits for new cars. The EU promoted the use of biofuels through the [[directive on the promotion of the use of biofuels and other renewable fuels for transport]] (2003/30/EC), also known as Biofuel Directive, which calls for countries across the EU aiming at replacing 5,75% of all transport fossil fuels ([[petrol]] and [[Diesel fuel|diesel]]) with [[biofuel]]s by 2010. None of these regulations, however, were based on [[carbon intensity]] of fuel. Fuel quality standards in the [[European Union]] are regulated by [[Directive 98/70/EC]].
Other European countries have their own mandates limiting consumption of conventional [[fossil fuel]]s by substituting to cleaner fuels in order to reduce [[greenhouse gas]] emissions, such as the [[United Kingdom]] [[Renewable Transport Fuel Obligation]] Program (RTFO), requiring transport fuel suppliers to ensure that 5% of all road vehicle fuel comes from sustainable renewable sources by 2010.<ref name="UKRTFO"/><ref name="UKfaq">{{cite web|url=http://www.dft.gov.uk/pgr/roads/environment/rtfo/faq |title=Renewable Transport Fuel Obligation: frequently asked questions |publisher=UK Department of Transport (DfT) |date= |accessdate=2009-04-25 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080907015825/http://www.dft.gov.uk/pgr/roads/environment/rtfo/faq |archivedate=September 7, 2008 }}</ref>
===UK Renewable Transport Fuel Obligation=== {{main|Renewable Transport Fuel Obligation}} The [[Renewable Transport Fuel Obligation]] is similar to California's LCFS in some aspects. Biofuel suppliers are required to report on the level of carbon savings and [[sustainability]] of the biofuels they supplied in order to receive Renewable Transport Fuel Certificates (RTFCs). Suppliers have to report on both the net GHG savings and the sustainability of the biofuels they supply according to the appropriate sustainability standards of the feedstocks from which they are produced and any potential indirect impacts of biofuel production, such as [[ILUC|indirect land-use change]] or changes to food and other commodity prices that are beyond the control of individual suppliers. Suppliers that do not submit a report will not be eligible for RTFO certificates.<ref name="UKRTFO"/><ref name="UKfaq"/>
Certificates can be claimed when renewable fuels are supplied and fuel duty is paid on them. At the end of the obligation period, these certificates may be redeemed to the RTFO Administrator to demonstrate compliance. Certificates can be traded, therefore, if obligated suppliers don't have enough certificates at the end of an obligation period they have to 'buy-out' the balance of their obligation by paying a buy-out price. The buy out price will be 15 pence per litre in the first two years.<ref name="UKRTFO"/><ref name="UKfaq"/>
===EU low-carbon fuel standard=== On January 31, 2007, the [[European Commission]] (EC) proposed new standards for transport fuels to reduce full life cycle emissions by up to 10 percent between 2011 and 2020<ref name="EU07">{{cite web |url=http://www.ens-newswire.com/ens/jan2007/2007-01-31-05.asp |title=EU Government Proposes Low Carbon Transport Fuel Standard |publisher= |author=[[Environment News Service]] |date=2007-01-31 |accessdate=2009-04-25}}</ref> This was three weeks after the California LCFS Directive was announced.<ref name="TwoBillion"/> The EU proposal aimed to encourage the development of low-carbon fuels and biofuels, considering reductions in greenhouse gas emissions caused by the production, transport and use of the suppliers fuels.<ref name="EU07"/>
On December 2008 the [[European Parliament]], among other measures to address [[climate change]] in the [[European Union]], approved amendments to the fuel quality directive (98/70) as well as replacing the [[Directive on the Promotion of the use of biofuels and other renewable fuels for transport|Biofuels Directive]] with a Directive on the promotion of Renewable Energy Sources as proposed by the European Commission. The revision of Directive 98/07/EC introduced a mechanism to monitor and reduce greenhouse gas emissions from the use of road transport fuels, requiring fuel suppliers to reduce GHG emissions by up to 10 percent by 2020 on a life cycle basis. Regarding land use changes, the EC was ordered to "''develop a concrete methodology to minimise greenhouse gas emissions caused by [[Indirect land use change impacts of biofuels|indirect land use changes]]''." The fuel directive includes provisions to promote sustainable biofuels which minimized the impacts of ILUC.<ref name="EU08">{{cite web|url=http://www.europarl.europa.eu/sides/getDoc.do?pubRef=-//EP//TEXT+TA+20081217+ITEMS+DOC+XML+V0//EN&language=EN#sdocta5 | title=Texts adopted Wednesday, 17 December 2008: Monitoring and reduction of greenhouse gas emissions from fuels |author=[[European Parliament]]|date=2008-12-17 |accessdate=2009-04-27}} ''For the text referring to ILUC see item 18''</ref><ref name= "ARBproposal"/> The approved goal of 10 percent reduction in greenhouse gas emissions can be achieved in several ways, and not exclusively from low-carbon fuels:<ref name="EU08"/><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.greencarcongress.com/2008/12/european-parl-4.html |title=European Parliament Climate Change Package Includes Vehicle CO<sub>2</sub> Regulations and Low Carbon Fuel Standard |publisher=Green Car Congress |date=2008-12-20 |accessdate=2009-04-26}}</ref> * At least 6% by 31 December 2020, compared to the EU-average level of life cycle greenhouse gas emissions per unit of energy from fossil fuels in 2010, obtained through the use of biofuels, alternative fuels and reductions in flaring and venting at production sites. * A further 2% reduction (subject to a review) obtained through the use of environmentally friendly [[carbon capture and storage]] technologies and electric vehicles. * An additional further 2% reduction obtained through the purchase of credits under the [[Clean Development Mechanism]] of the [[Kyoto Protocol]]. The Commission is continuing development of the EU LCFS, in particular on the methodology for fossil fuel emissions, has recently consulted<ref>http://ec.europa.eu/environment/air/transport/pdf/art7a.pdf</ref> on various aspects of the implementation and responses have been published.<ref>http://circa.europa.eu/Public/irc/env/fuel_quality/library?l=/article_7a/2009_consultation&vm=detailed&sb=Title</ref> Further work is underway to address Indirect Land Use Change emissions. Two modelling exercises and a model comparison exercise are being carried out to better understand the scale and nature of indirect land use change due to biofuels before the Commission makes proposals to address it.
On June 10, 2010, the EC adopted guidelines explaining how the Renewable Energy Directive (RED) should be implemented, as the Directive came into effect in December 2010.<ref name=EC0610/><ref name=GCC0610/><ref name=BBC0610/> Three measures focus on the criteria for sustainability of biofuels and how to control that only sustainable biofuels are used in the EU. First, the Commission is encouraging E.U. nations, industry and [[NGO]]s to set up voluntary schemes to certify biofuel sustainability. Second, the EC laid down the rules to protect untouched nature, such as forests, wetlands and protected areas, and third, a set of rules to guarantee that biofuels deliver substantial reduction in [[Life cycle assessment#Well-to-wheel|well-to-wheel]] [[greenhouse gas emissions]].<ref name=EC0610/><ref name=GCC0610/>
====Sustainable biofuel certificates==== The EC decided to request governments, industry and NGO's to set up voluntary schemes to certify biofuel sustainability for all types of biofuels, including those imported into the EU.<ref name=EC0610>{{cite web|url=http://europa.eu/rapid/pressReleasesAction.do?reference=IP/10/711&format=HTML&aged=0&language=EN&guiLanguage=en|title=Commission sets up system for certifying sustainable biofuels|publisher=European Commission|date=2010-06-10|accessdate=2010-06-13}}</ref><ref name=GCC0610>{{cite web|url=http://www.greencarcongress.com/2010/06/ecsust-20100610.html#more|title=European Commission Sets Up System for Certifying Sustainable Biofuels|publisher=[[Green Car Congress]]|date=2010-06-10|accessdate=2010-06-13}}</ref> According to the EC, the overall majority of biofuels are produced in the EU, and for 2007, only 26% of [[biodiesel]] and 31% of [[ethanol fuel|bioethanol]] consumed in the EU was imported, mainly from [[Brazil]] and the [[United States]].<ref name=BBC0610>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/science_and_environment/10283258.stm|title=EU biofuels need to be certified for sustainability|publisher=BBC News|author=Mark Kinver|date=2010-06-10|accessdate=2010-06-13}}</ref> The Commission set standards that must be met for these schemes to gain EU recognition. One of the main criteria is that the certification scheme must be interdependently audited and fraud-resistant. Auditors must check the whole production chain, from the farmer and mill to the filling station ([[Life cycle assessment#Well-to-wheel|well-to-wheel life cycle]]). Auditors must check all the paper and inspect a sample of the farmers, mills and traders, and also whether the land where the feedstock for the ethanol is produced has been indeed farm land before and not a tropical forest or protected area.<ref name=GCC0610/> The certificates are to guarantee that all the biofuels sold under the label are sustainable and produced under the criteria set by the Renewable Energy Directive.<ref name=EC0610_2>{{cite web|url=http://europa.eu/rapid/pressReleasesAction.do?reference=MEMO/10/247&format=HTML&aged=0&language=en&guiLanguage=en|title=Commission sets up system for certifying sustainable biofuels: MEMO/10/247|publisher=[[European Commission]]|date=2010-06-10|accessdate=2010-06-13}}</ref> Several private certification systems originally designed for sustainability more generally have adapted their standards to qualify for recognition under the Renewable Energy Directive, including the [[Sustainable biofuel#Roundtable on Sustainable Biofuels|Roundtable on Sustainable Biomaterials]] and [[Bonsucro]].<ref name="SolomonBailis2013">{{cite book|author1=Christine Moser|author2=Tina Hildebrandt|author3=Robert Bailis|editor=Barry D. Solomon|others=Robert Bailis|title=Sustainable Development of Biofuels in Latin America and the Caribbean|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=TzcdnwEACAAJ|date=14 November 2013|publisher=Springer New York|isbn=978-1-4614-9274-0|pages=27–69|chapter=International Sustainability Standards and Certification}}</ref>
Environmental groups complained the measures "are too weak to halt a dramatic increase in deforestation."<ref name=BBC0610/><ref name=Greenpeace0610/> According to [[Greenpeace]] "[[Indirect land use change impacts of biofuels]] (ILUC) production still are not properly addressed" because if not properly regulated, "ILUC impacts will continue causing major biodiversity loss and more greenhosuse gas emissions."<ref name=Greenpeace0610>{{cite web|url=http://www.greenpeace.org/eu-unit/press-centre/press-releases2/broken-biofuel-policies-still|title=Broken biofuel policies still driving rainforest destruction|publisher=Greenpeace European unit|date=2010-06-10|accessdate=2010-06-13}}</ref> On the other hand, industry representatives welcomed the introduction of a certification system and some dismissed the concerns regarding the lack of criteria about ILUC.<ref name=BBC0610/><ref name=NYT0610>{{cite news|url=http://green.blogs.nytimes.com/2010/06/11/parsing-europes-new-biofuel-rules/?emc=eta1|title=Parsing Europe's New Biofuel Rules|author=James Kanter|publisher=[[New York Times]]|date=2010-06-11 |accessdate=2010-06-13}}</ref><ref name=Unica0610/>[[UNICA, Brazil|UNICA]], the Brazilian ethanol producers association welcome the rules more cautiously, as they consider "''that gaps in the rules needed to be filled in so the "industry has a clear framework within which to operate".''"<ref name=NYT0610/><ref name=Unica0610/> Some other industry organizations also said that further clarification is needed in order to implement the Renewable Energy Directive.<ref name=Unica0610>{{cite web|url=http://unica.com.br/clipping/show.asp?cppCode=5C3F6D12-67A2-4614-8746-FBC406C74D38|title=Trade bodies welcome EU biofuels rules, but call for more guidance|publisher=[[UNICA, Brazil]]|author=Platts Commodity News|date=2010-06-11|accessdate=2010-06-13|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://archive.is/20110706154801/http://unica.com.br/clipping/show.asp?cppCode=5C3F6D12-67A2-4614-8746-FBC406C74D38|archivedate=2011-07-06|df=}}</ref>
The EC clarified that it would publish a report on [[Indirect land use change impacts of biofuels|the impacts of indirect land use]] by the end of 2010, as requested in the Renewable Energy Directive and on the basis of recently released reports that suggest that biofuels are saving greenhouse gas emissions.<ref name=EC0610_2/>
====Protecting untouched nature==== The rules set by the Commission establish that biofuels should not be made from [[feedstock]]s from [[tropical forest]]s or recently deforested areas, drained [[peatland]], [[wetland]] or highly [[Biodiversity|biodiverse]] areas. The corresponding Communication explains how this should be assessed and as an example, it makes it clear that the conversion of a forest to a [[palm oil]] plantation would not meet the sustainability requirements.<ref name=EC0610/><ref name=GCC0610/><ref name=BBC0610/>
====Promote only biofuels with high greenhouse gas savings==== The Commission reiterated that Member States have to meet binding, national targets for renewable energy and that only those biofuels with high [[greenhouse gas emission]] savings count for the national targets. The corresponding Communication explains how to make the calculation, which not only includes [[carbon dioxide]] (CO<sub>2</sub>), but also [[methane]] (CH<sub>4</sub>) and [[nitrous oxide]] (N<sub>2</sub>O), both stronger greenhouse gases than CO<sub>2</sub>. Biofuels must deliver greenhouse gas savings of at least 35% compared to [[fossil fuel]]s, rising to 50% in 2017 and to 60%, for biofuels from new plants, in 2018.<ref name=EC0610/><ref name=GCC0610/><ref name=EC0610_2/>

'''Magnetically-assisted slip casting''' is a manufacturing technique that uses [[anisotropic]] stiff [[nanoparticle]] platelets in a [[ceramic]], metal or polymer functional matrix to produce<ref>{{Cite journal|title = Magnetically assisted slip casting of bioinspired heterogeneous composites|url = http://www.nature.com/nmat/journal/vaop/ncurrent/full/nmat4419.html|journal = Nature Materials|date = 2015-09-21|issn = 1476-4660|volume = 14|doi = 10.1038/nmat4419|first = Hortense|last = Le Ferrand|first2 = Florian|last2 = Bouville|first3 = Tobias P.|last3 = Niebel|first4 = André R.|last4 = Studart|pages=1172–1179|pmid=26390326}}</ref> layered objects that can mimic natural objects such as [[nacre]]. Each layer of platelets is oriented in a different direction, giving the resulting object greater strength. The inventors claimed that the process is 10x faster than commercial [[3D printing]]. The magnetisation and orientation of the ceramic platelets has been patented.<ref name=zme>{{Cite web|title = Artificial tooth is as good as the real deal|url = http://www.zmescience.com/medicine/magnetic-casting-artificial-enamel-827834/|accessdate = 2015-09-29 |date= September 29, 2015 |first=Alexandru |last=Micu |publisher=ZME}}</ref>
== Technique ==
The technique involves pouring a suspension of magnetized ceramic micro-plates. Pores in the plaster mold absorb the liquid from the suspension, solidifying the material from the outside in. The particles are subjected to a strong [[magnetic field]] as they solidify that causes them to align in one direction. The field’s orientation is changed at regular intervals, moving the plates still in suspension, without disturbing already-solidified plates. By varying the composition of the suspension and the direction of the platelets, a continuous process can produce multiple layers with differing material properties in a single object. The resulting objects can closely imitate their natural models.<ref name=zme/>
== Artificial tooth ==
Researchers produced an artificial tooth whose microstructure mimicked that of a real tooth. The outer layers, corresponding to enamel, were hard and structurally complex. The outer layers contained glass [[nanoparticles]] and [[aluminium oxide]] plates were aligned perpendicular to the surface. After the outer layers hardened, a second suspension was poured. It contained no glass, and the plates were aligned horizontally to the surface of the tooth. These deeper layers were tougher, resembling [[dentine]]. The tooth was then cooked at 1,600 degrees to compact and harden the material — a process known as [[sintering]]. The last step involved filling remaining pores with a synthetic [[monomer]] used in [[dentistry]], which [[polymerizes]] after treatment.<ref name=zme/> Hardness and durability approximated that of both the enamel and dentine of a tooth.<ref>{{Cite web|title = Creating Fake Teeth as Strong as the Real Deal|url = http://www.rdmag.com/articles/2015/09/creating-fake-teeth-strong-real-deal|date=September 29, 2015 |first=Greg |last=Watry,|accessdate = 2015-09-29 |publisher=R&D}}</ref>
